title: Control Flow
text:
Today

Control flow

Choices
Loops


We will focus on primarily Chapter 5 from Advanced R.

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
Control Flow

Can be seen in the following ways:

Choices

if/else and switch statements
Includes debugging actions (e.g. errors, tryCatch)

Loops

for/while loops


Allows us to get through one process

title: Control Flow
section: Why would we use control flow?
text:
Why would we use control flow?

Different processes/outcomes for certain actions

e.g. process control: stop machine if variance is high
e.g. certain event on map: place unique symbol there

Repetition across sequence

e.g. multiply 3 to each element in array

Automation

e.g. simulations

title: Control Flow
text:
Situation

Suppose we play one half-inning of a baseball game. Keep in mind, we have the following:

3 outs to end the half-inning
For each play, it results in a single, HR, or out



We will use this as our motivating example for our understanding of choices and loops.

title: Control Flow
text:
Choices

In R: can be seen as if/else structure, ifelse() function, or switch() function

Completes task based on condition
e.g. do this if single is hit, do this otherwise

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
ifelse()

Suppose I want to work with multiple logical values (i.e. element-wise comparison)

Use ifelse() statement

First argument: conditional
Second argument: result if element-wise condition is true
Third argument: result if element-wise condition is false




nums <- c(2, 5, 3, 8, 1)
ifelse(nums %% 2 == 0, nums, 0)

[1] 2 0 0 8 0

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: if/else statement

runs <- c(0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 4, 0, 0, 0)
scored <- ifelse(runs > 0, T, F)
scored

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE

title: Control Flow
text:
Activity: if/else statement

runs <- c(0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 4, 0, 0, 0)
scored <- ifelse(runs > 0, T, F)
scored

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE


Question 3: Suppose if we have less than 0 runs, I want to output an NA. How can I change the ifelse() statement above to do this?

title: Control Flow
text:
Alternative: case_when()

From dplyr package


library(dplyr)
case_when(runs > 0 ~ "True", 
          runs == 0 ~ "False", 
          runs < 0 ~ "Runs are invalid.")

[1] "False" "True"  "False" "False" "False" "True"  "False" "False" "False"

title: Control Flow
text:
switch()

Used on a character to perform certain action


stat = "mean"
switch(stat, 
       mean = mean(nums),
       median = median(nums), 
       sd = sd(nums), 
       stop("Invalid stat request."))

[1] 3.8

title: Control Flow
text:
Activity: switch()
Question 4: Write a switch() function that takes a single character and does the following:

Print 1 for “single”
Print 4 for “homerun”
Stop otherwise


result = "single"
switch(result, 
       single = 1,
       homerun = 4,
       stop("Invalid request."))

[1] 1

title: Control Flow
text:
Loops

Iterating over items in a vector

item in array
object in sequence (e.g. i in 1:10)

Actions happen within loop


for (i in 1:10){
  print(i)
}

[1] 1
[1] 2
[1] 3
[1] 4
[1] 5
[1] 6
[1] 7
[1] 8
[1] 9
[1] 10

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
For-loop notes

Pre-allocating the output container is recommended

Replacement is more efficient than adding to the output container
e.g. vector("list", length(x)), rep(-1, length(x))

Be careful about the vector you iterate over

: can iterate 1 up or 1 down
Specify which vector to iterate through

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
While loops and repeats

Two specific types of for loops:

while loops: repeat until condition is not satisfied
repeat: repeat forever until break occurs

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: while loop

xVal = 6
while(xVal < 10){
  print(xVal)
  xVal <- xVal + 1
}

[1] 6
[1] 7
[1] 8
[1] 9

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
The argument against for loops

R succeeds when using vectorized operations

e.g. colSums(), adding two vectors together
A for-loop does so element by element, making things slow

If possible:

Use an apply() function
Use the map() function

title: Control Flow
text:
apply() function

Functional operation, usually done on a list (or data frame)
apply(x, margin, function)

x is an array
margin specifies direction function will be applied over

1 for function completed on each row, 2 on each column

function is the function being applied to object

title: Control Flow
text:
map() function

# For loop
y <- list()
for (i in seq_along(x)) {
  y[[i]] <- my_fun(i) 
}

# Map
y <- map(x, my_fun)

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: matrix

myMat <- matrix(rnorm(100, 0, 1), nrow = 5, ncol = 20)


timerFor <- Sys.time()
columnSums <- rep(-1, ncol(myMat))
for (i in 1:ncol(myMat)){
  columnSums[i] <- sum(myMat[, i])
}
Sys.time() - timerFor

Time difference of 0.004554987 secs

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Background
The second problem set will contain various problems related to the following:

Control flow (Ch. 5, AR)
Functions (Ch. 6, AR)
Functionals (partly, Ch. 9, AR)

Do note that other traits of R may show up in these problems. Make sure to carefully read and follow directions for each problem.
All problems will center around the DOHMH Dog Bite Data collected by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene in NYC. You can download the data and view its metadata here.
Additionally, you will use the following packages below:

library(tidyverse)
library(lobstr)

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Q1: Data Preparation






Important(a)



Gather the data from the resource mentioned above and load the data into your global environment. Name the dataset dogs.

dogs <- read.csv("../data/dogs.csv")









Important(b)



Create a function named countMissing that takes in some atomic vector x and a singular value val and counts the number of times val shows up in the atomic vector x. You will return that number as a double value named count.
For any x that is not an atomic vector, return a message (as a character) that states that x is of the wrong type.

countMissing <- function(x, val){
  if (typeof(x) %in% c("integer", "double", "character", "logical")){
    count <- sum(x == val)
    return(count)
  }
  return("x is of the wrong type.")
}









Important(c)



Find out how missing values are handled in the dogs data (i.e. what is a missing value labeled as?). Then, use the countMissing function to find the number of missing values in the Breed column of the dogs data.

countMissing(dogs$Breed, "")

[1] 2276










Important(d)



As an extension to part (c), find the number of missing values in each column in dogs using a for-loop.

missing <- c()
for (i in 1:ncol(dogs)){
  missing <- c(missing, countMissing(dogs[[i]], ""))
}
missing

[1]     0     0     0  2276 17965     0     0     0 10579










Important(e)



In part (d), explain how the for-loop works on the dogs data using the countMissing function.








Important(f)



Repeat parts (d) and (e), but use a functional instead of a for-loop.

sapply(dogs, countMissing, "")

  UniqueID DateOfBite    Species      Breed        Age     Gender SpayNeuter 
         0          0          0       2276      17965          0          0 
   Borough    ZipCode 
         0      10579

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
For these exercises, we will learn how to use the lobstr package to get information about objects in our environment.
Goal: By the end of these exercises, you will be able to determine whether an operation makes a copy, and compute the amount of memory each object occupies.
You will create a separate .qmd file and complete the following exercises that will then be committed and pushed in your SDS 270 repository.

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
For these exercises, we will learn how to use the lobstr package to get information about objects in our environment.
Goal: By the end of these exercises, you will be able to determine whether an operation makes a copy, and compute the amount of memory each object occupies.
You will create a separate .qmd file and complete the following exercises that will then be committed and pushed in your SDS 270 repository.

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
Exercises

Measuring Memory
First, load the lobstr package. This package contains many functions that will make it easier for us to figure out what R is doing under the hood. Also load the tidyverse package.

library(lobstr)

Warning: package 'lobstr' was built under R version 4.4.3

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.6.0
✔ ggplot2   4.0.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.2.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Your workspace should be empty.






ImportantQ1:



Use ls() to list the objects in your workspace. If it is not empty, use the broom icon in the Environment tab in RStudio to empty it.

# PUT SOLUTION HERE



Before we do anything, how much memory is being used by our R session?

mem_used()

85.34 MB


Recall that a byte is eight bits. A byte is a very small amount of information, typically used to store one character. A kilobyte is 1000 bytes, and a megabyte is 1000 kilobytes, etc. You should familiarize yourself briefly with the orders of magnitude of data.
Now suppose we add some things to our workspace. We can add objects, functions, or load packages. Does loading a package increase the memory used by our session?






ImportantQ2:



Use the library() command to load the broom package. Then check the memory usage with mem_used(). Does loading a package increase the amount of memory used? By how much?

# PUT SOLUTION HERE









ImportantQ3:



What about loading a data set? Use the data() command to load the iris data set. Does that increase the memory usage? By how much?

# PUT SOLUTION HERE









ImportantQ4:



Use obj_size() to measure the amount of memory that iris takes up. Was the increase you observed previously equal to this amount?

# PUT SOLUTION HERE





Making Copies
As much fun as it is to make copies, each copy occupies memory. Generally, we want to minimize the amount of memory that our code needs to run.
Let’s store the amount of memory we are currently using.

before <- mem_used()

Note the memory location of the iris data frame.

ref(iris)

█ [1:0x24bb2e1f3f8] <df[,5]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x24ba95e8860] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x24ba95e6f60] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x24ba95e7460] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x24ba95e9260] <dbl> 
└─Species = [6:0x24ba76e1610] <fct> 


Note that we can bind a second name my_iris to the iris data frame, without making a copy.

my_iris <- iris
ref(my_iris)

█ [1:0x24bb2e1f3f8] <df[,5]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x24ba95e8860] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x24ba95e6f60] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x24ba95e7460] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x24ba95e9260] <dbl> 
└─Species = [6:0x24ba76e1610] <fct> 


Now let’s change the data frame in a way that forces a copy to be made.

my_iris <- my_iris |>
  mutate(sepal_area = Sepal.Length * Sepal.Width)
ref(my_iris)

█ [1:0x24bb0048cd8] <df[,6]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x24ba95e8860] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x24ba95e6f60] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x24ba95e7460] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x24ba95e9260] <dbl> 
├─Species = [6:0x24ba76e1610] <fct> 
└─sepal_area = [7:0x24ba95eb560] <dbl> 


Note that the memory locations of my_iris and iris are not the same anymore. However, the memory locations of the underlying vectors are the same!






ImportantQ5:



Use before and mem_used() to calculate how much extra memory the copy of my_iris occupies.

# PUT SOLUTION HERE









ImportantQ6:



Is the difference you observed above equal to the size of the new column we created? Why or why not?

# PUT SOLUTION HERE



Different representations of the same data may have different memory footprints. Suppose we change the iris data set into its long format.

iris_long <- iris |>
  pivot_longer(-Species, names_to = "type", values_to = "measurement")







ImportantQ7:



Does iris_long take up the same amount of memory as iris? Why or why not?

# PUT SOLUTION HERE



We know that tibbles are like data.frames. Do they take up the same amount of memory?

before <- mem_used()
iris_tbl <- iris_long |>
  as_tibble()
mem_used() - before

-6.70 kB

class(iris_tbl)

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"


Does converting a data.frame to a tbl force a copy?

ref(iris_tbl)

█ [1:0x24baef8daa8] <tibble[,3]> 
├─Species = [2:0x24ba70e6250] <fct> 
├─type = [3:0x24ba6dddf50] <chr> 
└─measurement = [4:0x24ba6dd6d50] <dbl> 

ref(iris_long)

█ [1:0x24bafe18d38] <tibble[,3]> 
├─Species = [2:0x24ba70e6250] <fct> 
├─type = [3:0x24ba6dddf50] <chr> 
└─measurement = [4:0x24ba6dd6d50] <dbl> 








ImportantQ8:



Discuss how using a tibble changes the memory footprint relative to using a data.frame.
PUT SOLUTION HERE




Tracing memory
Unfortunately, due to various complications and optimizations, it’s not always possible to reason ahead of time about whether R will make a copy of an object. Instead, we can use the tracemem() function to have R tell us whether it makes a copy and why.
First, note the memory location of iris.

tracemem(iris)

[1] "<0000024BB2E1F3F8>"


We are now tracing this memory location. Some types of computations we make on iris do not require making a copy.

iris |>
  pull(Petal.Length) |>
  mean()

[1] 3.758


However, if we modify iris using mutate(), a copy does get made.

iris |>
  mutate(petal_area = Petal.Length * Petal.Width) |>
  as_tibble()

tracemem[0x0000024bb2e1f3f8 -> 0x0000024bac137708]: initialize <Anonymous> mutate_cols mutate.data.frame mutate as_tibble eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main

tracemem[0x0000024bb2e1f3f8 -> 0x0000024ba7a868b8]: new_data_frame vec_data as.list dplyr_col_modify.data.frame dplyr_col_modify mutate.data.frame mutate as_tibble eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main

Experiment with different operations after invoking tracemem(). Can you get a feel for what operations induce copies?

title: Functions
text:
Last Time

Control flow

Choices
Loops

title: Functions
text:
Today

Functions

Components
Lexical scoping
The dots
Exiting a function
Types of functions



We will focus on primarily Chapter 6 from Advanced R.

title: Functions
Functions
Functions
text:
Exception: Primitive Functions

Call C code specifically

Using older infrastructure
All within base package



typeof(sum)

[1] "builtin"

title: Functions
text:
Function Composition

Think of it like a math function

f(g(x))

Can nest: f(g(x))
Can use intermediate objects: y <- g(x); f(y)
Can pipe: x |> g() |> f()

title: Functions
text:
Example: Function Composition

x <- 2

sqrt(exp(x)) # Nesting

[1] 2.718282

y <- exp(x); sqrt(y) # Intermediate

[1] 2.718282

x |> exp() |> sqrt() # Piping

[1] 2.718282

title: Functions
text:
Scoping

Remember assignment?


vect <- c(2, 5, 3, 2, 1)


We investigate scoping

How do we find the value associated with the name?

title: Functions
text:
Lexical Scoping

Lexical?

“parse-time”, not “run-time”

Following four rules:

Name masking
Functions vs. variables
A fresh start
Dynamic lookup

title: Functions
text:
1. Name Masking

Names masked until needed

Object names masked in function environment if defined in function
Function \(\rightarrow\) outer function \(\rightarrow\) package \(\rightarrow\) environment



x <- 5; y <- 6; z <- 7

myFunct2 <- function(){
  x <- 1; y <- 2; z <- 3
  return(c(x, y, z))
}

myFunct2()

[1] 1 2 3

title: Functions
Functions
text:
3. A Fresh Start

New call = new environment

Memoryless between function calls



a <- 10
myFunct5 <- function(){
  a <- a + 1
  a
}

myFunct5()

[1] 11

myFunct5()

[1] 11



Question: How can we update the value of a for the next function call?

title: Functions
text:
4. Dynamic Lookup

Procrastinate and check functionality when needed

R looks for values when function is called, not defined
Function mistakes will not be apparent until you run it



a <- 15
myFunct5()

[1] 16

a <- 20
myFunct5()

[1] 21

title: Functions
text:
Extension: Explicit Calling

This extends to creating functions of same name as others


stats <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
mean <- function(x){return(1)}
mean(stats)

[1] 1



Solution: reference package where function comes from


base::mean(stats)

[1] 3

Functions
text:
R is Lazy!

Arguments only evaluated if accessed

Leads to undiagnosed errors

Promises are used

Delayed computation
Environment for called function
Cached values

title: Functions
text:
Example

What issues do we have here?


addFunct <- function(x, y, z){
  x + y
}

addFunct(2, 3)

[1] 5

title: Functions
text:
The Dots (...)

Passes arguments to other functions

Uses?

Nesting functions
Accessing methods of other parent classes

e.g. apply() functions

Useful for S3 generics

Need a way to allow methods to take arbitrary extra arguments

title: Functions
Functions
text:
Capture the Dots

catch_the_dots <- function(...){
  list(...)
}

catch_the_dots(whatever = "hi", "bye")

$whatever
[1] "hi"

[[2]]
[1] "bye"

title: Functions
text:
Generic Functions and Dots

Can use arguments that a generic function doesn’t accept initially


args(plot)

function (x, y, ...) 
NULL

plot(rnorm(20), rnorm(20), main = "Random Plot")

title: Functions
text:
Check Arguments

body(plot)

UseMethod("plot")

args(plot.default)

function (x, y = NULL, type = "p", xlim = NULL, ylim = NULL, 
    log = "", main = NULL, sub = NULL, xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL, 
    ann = par("ann"), axes = TRUE, frame.plot = axes, panel.first = NULL, 
    panel.last = NULL, asp = NA, xgap.axis = NA, ygap.axis = NA, 
    ...) 
NULL

title: Functions
Functions
text:
Invisibility



divides <- function(x, y){
  x / y # implicit return
}
divides(8, 4)

[1] 2




divides <- function(x, y){
  invisible(x / y)
}
divides(8, 4)



print(divides(8, 4))

[1] 2

(divides(8, 4))

[1] 2




Use invisible() to prevent automatic printing

title: Functions
text:
Errors and Exit Handlers

To throw an error: stop()
To set up an exit handler: on.exit()

Undoes changes done in global state



errorFunct <- function(x){
  stop("Error!")
}

errorFunct2 <- function(x){
  on.exit(cat("Goodbye!\n"), add = T)
  stop("Error!")
}

errorFunct(5)

Error in `errorFunct()`:
! Error!

errorFunct2(5)

Error in `errorFunct2()`:
! Error!

title: Functions
text:
Function Forms

Prefix: f(x, y)
Infix: x %f% y
Replacement: f(x) <- y
Special: if, [[, for

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 2: Control Flow
text:
ImportantQ1:



Describe what is going on in each part of the code step-by-step. What mechanisms are being used?








ImportantQ2:



We’ll add to the specific scenario of hitting a single, where we need to tally up a run if the number of people on base is equal to 3. Use some form of an if-else choice to do this.








ImportantQ3:



Suppose if we have less than 0 runs, I want to output an NA. How can I change the ifelse() statement above to do this?








ImportantQ4:



Write a switch() function that takes a single character and does the following:

Print 1 for “single”
Print 4 for “home run”
Stop otherwise









ImportantQ5:



Write a for-loop on the revised if-else chain that runs through this process 20 times, storing the results for outs and runs in individual data structures.








ImportantQ6:



Write a while-loop that continues the out operation until 3 outs are recorded, storing the results for outs and runs in individual data structures.

title: Functionals
text:
Functions

Components
Lexical scoping
The dots
Exiting a function
Types of functions

title: Functionals
text:
Today

Functionals

What they are
Usage

apply() statements

What they are
Different types
Examples



We will focus on primarily Chapter 9 from Advanced R.

title: Functionals
text:
Functionals

Take a function as an input and returns a vector

Can run function call as we iterate through some data structure
Alternative to for loops

Cleaner code; known behavior

title: Functionals
text:
Functional Types


apply()

base R family of functionals

apply(), lapply(), vapply(), tapply(), replicate()



map()

From purrr (which is part of tidyverse)

map(), map2(), pmap(), walk()

title: Functionals
text:
apply()

Returns a vector after applying a function to the margins of some array or matrix
apply(x, MARGIN, FUN, ...)

x: the array/matrix used for iteration
MARGIN: 1 for cycling through rows, 2 for cycling through columns
FUN: the function to be used on each row/column

title: Functionals
text:
Different Types

lapply(x, FUN, ...): cycles through atomic vector or list; applies function to each element and returns a list

x and FUN in use

vapply(x, FUN, FUN.VALUE, ...): cycles through atomic vector or list; applies function to each element and returns a vector

x and FUN in use
FUN.VALUE is a template for each run

title: Functionals
text:
Different Types

tapply(x, INDEX, FUN): cycles through a ragged array (i.e. with some group component); applies function to each group within array

x and FUN in use
INDEX specifies the grouping vector

replicate(n, expr): repeated evaluation of an expression

n specifies number of iterates
expr refers to the function call used

section: Example: Getting mpg Mean across Different Groups
text:
Example: Getting mpg Mean across Different Groups

Let’s factorize the cyl column so we look at the 3 groups in there:


mtcars$cyl <- factor(mtcars$cyl)


Can use tapply() to find the mean mpg in each group of the number of cylinders


tapply(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl, mean)

       4        6        8 
26.66364 19.74286 15.10000

title: Functionals
text:

Suppose we want to generate 100 random sample of 10 cars from the mtcars dataset

title: Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
text:
In these exercises, we will learn how to find out about functions and the principles of lexical scoping. We will investigate a use of the dots.
Goal: By the end of this lab, you should be able to retrieve information about functions and understand how lexical scoping works in R.

title: Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
text:
Learning about Functions
There are many functions in R, and nobody knows how all of them work. From time to time it is helpful to retrieve information about these functions. The documentation in help() is great to read, but it doesn’t always provide the information you need.

Arguments
The first question you may have is what arguments a function takes. We can learn this by running args() on the bare name of the function.

args(dplyr::filter)

function (.data, ..., .by = NULL, .preserve = FALSE) 
NULL



args(print)

function (x, ...) 
NULL


Note that for S3 generic function like print(), you can also find the arguments for specific methods.

args(print.data.frame)

function (x, ..., digits = NULL, quote = FALSE, right = TRUE, 
    row.names = TRUE, max = NULL) 
NULL

title: Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
text:
Scoping
R uses lexical scoping. This means that when R looks for the value of names, it depends on the state of things when the function is defined.

Name Masking
R looks for variables inside a function definition first (local variables), but if it can’t find them, it looks in the parent environment. In this case, when my_fun() is executed, R looks for the value of global_var. Many programming languages will throw an error in this situation, because global_var is not defined in the environment created by my_fun(). However, R just keeps looking for global_var in the parent environment (which in this case is the global environment).

global_var <- 21

my_fun <- function(x) {
  x + global_var
}

my_fun(3)

[1] 24



environment(my_fun)

<environment: R_GlobalEnv>


Note also that if we try to re-define global_var inside the function definition, we are masking the name global_var.

my_fun2 <- function(x) {
  global_var <- 99
  x + global_var
}

my_fun2(3)

[1] 102


Note the difference reported by findGlobals().

codetools::findGlobals(my_fun)

[1] "{"          "+"          "global_var"



codetools::findGlobals(my_fun2)

[1] "{"  "+"  "<-"




A Fresh Start
Local variables that are created inside a function never see the light of day in the parent environment.

my_fun3 <- function(x) {
  local_var <- 7
  x + global_var
}

my_fun3(3)

[1] 24



local_var

Error:
! object 'local_var' not found








ImportantQ4



Why would it be a bad idea to allow the value of local variables to persist outside of the function?




Dynamic Lookup
Because of name masking, values of objects in the parent environment can affect the behavior of a function. This behavior is often useful in data analysis scripts, but can be problematic in more formal programming.
This means that if we reset the value of global_var, we change the behavior of my_fun().

global_var <- 15

my_fun(3)

[1] 18








ImportantQ5



Give an example of a situation in which dynamic lookup is helpful.








ImportantQ6



Give an example of a situation in which dynamic lookup could be problematic.

In these data sets, we will gather some basic information.






ImportantQ1



Create an object named datasets that has an appropriate data structure that can house all three datasets specified.



Using a For Loop

Create an empty vector of length 3 that will store the number of observations in each of the datasets. From there, write a for-loop that gathers the number of observations in each dataset, storing that number inside the created vector.
Write this in between the Sys.time code.




Using apply()

Redo Q2 by using an appropriate apply() statement instead.




Comparing the Two Methods

In these exercises, we will learn how to find out about functions and the principles of lexical scoping. We will investigate a use of the dots.
Goal: By the end of this lab, you should be able to retrieve information about functions and understand how lexical scoping works in R.

title: Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
text:
Learning about Functions
There are many functions in R, and nobody knows how all of them work. From time to time it is helpful to retrieve information about these functions. The documentation in help() is great to read, but it doesn’t always provide the information you need.

Arguments
The first question you may have is what arguments a function takes. We can learn this by running args() on the bare name of the function.

args(dplyr::filter)

function (.data, ..., .by = NULL, .preserve = FALSE) 
NULL



args(print)

function (x, ...) 
NULL


Note that for S3 generic function like print(), you can also find the arguments for specific methods.

args(print.data.frame)

function (x, ..., digits = NULL, quote = FALSE, right = TRUE, 
    row.names = TRUE, max = NULL) 
NULL

title: Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
Exercises from Week 4, Lecture 1: Functions
text:
Scoping
R uses lexical scoping. This means that when R looks for the value of names, it depends on the state of things when the function is defined.

Name Masking
R looks for variables inside a function definition first (local variables), but if it can’t find them, it looks in the parent environment. In this case, when my_fun() is executed, R looks for the value of global_var. Many programming languages will throw an error in this situation, because global_var is not defined in the environment created by my_fun(). However, R just keeps looking for global_var in the parent environment (which in this case is the global environment).

global_var <- 21

my_fun <- function(x) {
  x + global_var
}

my_fun(3)

[1] 24



environment(my_fun)

<environment: R_GlobalEnv>


Note also that if we try to re-define global_var inside the function definition, we are masking the name global_var.

my_fun2 <- function(x) {
  global_var <- 99
  x + global_var
}

my_fun2(3)

[1] 102


Note the difference reported by findGlobals().

codetools::findGlobals(my_fun)

[1] "{"          "+"          "global_var"



codetools::findGlobals(my_fun2)

[1] "{"  "+"  "<-"




A Fresh Start
Local variables that are created inside a function never see the light of day in the parent environment.

my_fun3 <- function(x) {
  local_var <- 7
  x + global_var
}

my_fun3(3)

[1] 24



local_var

Error:
! object 'local_var' not found








ImportantQ4



Why would it be a bad idea to allow the value of local variables to persist outside of the function?
PUT SOLUTION HERE




Dynamic Lookup
Because of name masking, values of objects in the parent environment can affect the behavior of a function. This behavior is often useful in data analysis scripts, but can be problematic in more formal programming.
This means that if we reset the value of global_var, we change the behavior of my_fun().

global_var <- 15

my_fun(3)

[1] 18








ImportantQ5



Give an example of a situation in which dynamic lookup is helpful.
PUT SOLUTION HERE








ImportantQ6



Give an example of a situation in which dynamic lookup could be problematic.
PUT SOLUTION HERE

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Q3:
In this question, we want to create frequency tables regarding the borough where the bite occurred, in which we have a frequency table for each gender mentioned in the dataset. In other words,

tapply(dogs$Borough, dogs$Gender, table)

$F

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
          770           985          1163           238          1204 
Staten Island 
          405 

$M

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
         1984          2584          2777           538          3343 
Staten Island 
         1115 

$U

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
         3271          3748          3754           706          4105 
Staten Island 
         1343 

#dogs |> group_by(Gender, Borough) |> summarize(count = n())

As you might have guessed, we’ll do this the convoluted (and the straight-forward way).






Important(a)



Replicate the table above by writing code that utilizes the following:

A list of size 3 that stores a frequency table of dog bites across boroughs in each element.
A loop that iterates through each observation in the dogs dataset.
A base R choice structure that…

Increases the number of dog bites in that borough within the gender


Hint: Consider how the list (and the elements within the list will be built). From there, consider how we would access the element in the element of the list, using the gender and current iteration to do so.

dogBiteList <- list()

for (i in 1:nrow(dogs)){
  if (!(dogs$Gender[i] %in% names(dogBiteList))){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]] = rep(0, 6)
  }
  if (dogs$Borough[i] == "Bronx"){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][1] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][1] + 1
  } else if (dogs$Borough[i] == "Brooklyn"){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][2] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][2] + 1
  } else if (dogs$Borough[i] == "Manhattan"){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][3] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][3] + 1
  } else if (dogs$Borough[i] == "Other"){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][4] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][4] + 1
  } else if (dogs$Borough[i] == "Queens"){
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][5] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][5] + 1
  } else {
    dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][6] = dogBiteList[[dogs$Gender[i]]][6] + 1
  }
}









Important(b)



Identify a functional that will allow you to run a function on each group related to a variable. Then, use this functional to produce the same list as seen in the introduction of this question.

tapply(dogs$Borough, dogs$Gender, table)

$F

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
          770           985          1163           238          1204 
Staten Island 
          405 

$M

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
         1984          2584          2777           538          3343 
Staten Island 
         1115 

$U

        Bronx      Brooklyn     Manhattan         Other        Queens 
         3271          3748          3754           706          4105 
Staten Island 
         1343

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Q4: Gambling
Let’s go gambling! We will create functions that run through two different types of games: one that involves a deck of cards and another that involves a spinning wheel.
This question involves using the sample() function in various ways. Read through the documentation to become familiar with how we would sample from a discrete number of outcomes with some probability.






Important(a)



Create a function named cards that takes in the following arguments:

wager: amount of money wagered
color: “red” or “black”
number: 1, 2, …, 13 (assume aces are 1, jacks are 11, queens are 12, and kings are 13)

You will use sample() functions to return a color and number (assume the probabilities are of equal chance). Return winnings, which will be of a combination of these outcomes minus the wager:

If card is “red”, bettor wins three times their wager.
If card is a face card, bettor wins half their wager.
If card is “black” and a 10, bettor wins half their wager.
Anything else results in no winnings.

For example, if a red jack is drawn, then the player wins 3.5x their wager back and we will return what they earned minus the wager they put in. As such, $10 wagered will return $25 in winnings.








Important(b)



Create a function named wheel that takes in the following arguments:

wager: amount of money wagered

Return winnings, which will be the net gain of the following spin probabilities:

10% chance that they win five times their wager
20% chance that they win their wager back
70% chance that they win no money back

For example, if $10 is wagered and they win on the 5x spot, they will get a net $40 in return.








Important(c)



Create a function named game that passes arguments without addressing them to the card and wheel games within the function. Use a sample() function with an if-else chain to determine which type of game they play, with the following specifications:

30% chance they play cards
70% chance they play the wheel

Return their net gain after playing the game.








Important(d)



Use the replicate() function to play the game 1000 times, with a wager of $10 each time. Take the cumsum() and plot these results across the number of iterations.








Important(e)



Re-do part (c) by using a vectorized if or switch.


When finished, commit and push this file to your SDS 270 repository.

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Q1: What’s Missing
This question centers on finding missing values from the dataset, but using certain choices and iteration we’ve mentioned in class. The whole question will center on the dogs dataset (that you will import in part (a)).






Important(a)



Gather the data from the resource mentioned above and load the data into your global environment. Name the dataset dogs.








Important(b)



Create a function named countMissing that takes in some atomic vector x and a singular value val and counts the number of times val shows up in the atomic vector x. You will return that number as a double value named count.
For any x that is not an atomic vector, return a message (as a character) that states that x is of the wrong type.








Important(c)



Find out how missing values are handled in the dogs data (i.e. what is a missing value labeled as?). Then, use the countMissing function to find the number of missing values in the Breed column of the dogs data.








Important(d)



As an extension to part (c), find the number of missing values in each column in dogs using a for-loop.








Important(e)



In part (d), explain how the for-loop works on the dogs data using the countMissing function.








Important(f)



Repeat parts (d) and (e), but use a functional instead of a for-loop.

title: Set #2 (50 pts)
text:
Q2: Dates
We now focus on data tidying but with an in-depth look at how certain functions can be written alternatively. We will once again use the dogs dataset.






Important(a)



Use the separate() function from the dplyr package to break the DateOfBite column into three columns: Month, Day, and Year. Keep the old column when doing so.








Important(b)



Create an if-else chain of statements that would convert a value named month into a two-digit number as a character corresponding to the month and reassign that double back to month. Thus,

month as “January” \(\rightarrow\) month as “01”
month as “February” \(\rightarrow\) month as “02”
…
month as “December” \(\rightarrow\) month as “12”









Important(c)



Modify code you’ve created from part (b) such that…

The if-else chain is engrained inside a for-loop, which iterates through all observations in the dogs dataset
We perform comparison and re-assignment to each element in the Month column









Important(d)



Use the unite() function from the dplyr package to combine the Month, Day, and Year columns into one column named date that links them together with -.








Important(e)



Redo parts (a-d) by using the case_match() and mutate() functions from dplyr in lieu of the if-else chain and for-loops. Additionally, combine the parts so they follow a chronological order with the use of the piping operator and unite the columns into a column named date2.








Important(f)



Discuss the efficiency and storage implications of using each of the two methods to modify the DateOfBite column.
